string.name: arrest
string.u: Basic First Aid for Cardiac Arrest:

resources.string: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is the most important medical procedure of all. If a person is in cardiac arrest and CPR is not performed, that person will die.
Regardless of how severe, almost all bleeding can be controlled. Mild bleeding will usually stop on its own. If severe bleeding is not controlled, it may lead to shock and eventually death.

string.name: burns
string.u: Basic First Aid for Cardiac Discomfort:

resources.string: The victim complains of a pain tightening his chest. The pain may radiate to other parts of the body (including the arm, shoulder, neck, lower jaw, or stomach). These signs may be accompanied by breathing difficulties, sweating, nausea, or even abdominal pain.
Command someone to call 911 or the medical alert system for the locale.

Immediately start chest compressions regardless of your training. Compress hard and fast in the center of the chest, allowing recoil between compressions. Hand this task over to those who are trained if and when they arrive.
If you are trained, use chest compressions and rescue breathing.
An AED should be applied and used. But it is essential not to delay chest compressions, so finding one should be commanded to someone else while you are doing chest compressions.
Avoid, if possible, any contact with the blood of the victim: ask him to compress the wound himself.

Otherwise,Cover the wound with a gauze or a cloth and apply direct pressure to stop the blood flow. Don\'t remove the cloth. Add more layers if needed. The cloth will help clots form to stop the flow.
Lay the victim in a horizontal position.
Ask someone present to alert the authorities or do it yourself if you are alone.
If the wound continues to bleed, compress it even more firmly.Continue compression on the wound until help arrives.
Wash your hands after doing these first aid.
Ask the victim questions: how long has this discomfort lasted? Is this the first time? Has the victim been hospitalized or is taking medication for this?
Ask someone present to immediately alert the rescuers(SAMU:190) , or do it yourself if you are alone.
Rest the victim in a comfortable position (lying down or, if desired, in a semi-sitting or sitting position).
Check regularly that the victim is conscious and is breathing normally.

Choking is a blockage of the upper airway by food or other objects, which prevents a person from breathing effectively. Choking can cause a simple coughing fit, but complete blockage of the airway may lead to death.
Give a maximum of 5 slaps on the back of the victim. After each slap, check if everything goes in order.
If the slaps in the back have no effect, give a maximum of 5 abdominal compressions.
If the problem is still not resolved, alternate 5 slaps on the back and 5 abdominal compressions.

If the victim becomes unconscious, place the victim gently on the ground and immediately alert the emergency services, then undertake a cardiopulmonary resuscitation starting with 30 chest compressions
Continue resuscitation until rescuers arrives or the victim resumes normal breathing.
Unconsciousness is when a person suddenly becomes unable to respond to stimuli and appears to be asleep. A person may be unconscious for a few seconds(as in fainting )or for longer periods of time.
Check that the victim does not react.
Check that the victim is breathing.
Turn the casualty to the side in a safe lateral position.
Ask someone to call emergency services, ask for help yourself if you are alone.
Regularly check if the victim is breathing until help arrives.
